elements.content: Single crystals of lithium d-isoascorbate monohydrate (LDAM), (C6H7O6Li·H2O), are grown by a solution growth method. The crystal structure of LDAM is solved using single crystal X-ray diffraction. The space group is orthorhombic P212121 with four formula units per unit cell and lattice parameters a = 7.7836(3) Å, b = 8.7456(3) Å, and c = 11.0368(4) Å. Solubility of the material in water is determined thermogravimetrically and found to have a positive temperature coefficient of solubility. Large optical quality single crystals are subsequently grown from aqueous solution by a slow cooling method. The crystal has a bulky prismatic habit and among the prominent faces the c face appears as the only principal morphological face. The crystal exhibits a (010) cleavage. Dielectric spectroscopy reveals a nearly Debye type Cole–Cole behavior with anisotropy in relaxation. Optical transmission range is found to be from 300 to 1400 nm. The principal refractive indices of this biaxial crystal, measured using Brewster’s angle method, at wavelengths 405, 543, and 632.8 nm, show high dispersion. The crystal is negative biaxial with 2V z = 107.8° (405 nm) and belongs to the Hobden class 3. Theoretically generated type 1 and type 2 second order phase matching curves match very well with the experimental results. The second-order nonlinear coefficient d 14 was determined to be 7 × 10–13 m/V. For the optimum phase matching direction (type 2), the second-order effective nonlinear coefficient and the walk off angle are determined to be 0.84 times d 14 and 3.5° respectively. The crystal possesses high multiple surface damage thresholds of 18 GW/cm2 and 8 GW/cm2 at laser wavelengths 1064 and 532 nm, respectively.

elements.content: Large, stable, and optical quality nonlinear optical lithium d-isoascorbate monohydrate crystals crystallizing in the space group P212121 are grown from solution. They exhibit high birefringence, collinear and noncollinear phase matching, anisotropic dielectric relaxation, high laser damage thresholds, etc. The refractive indices and generated phase matching curves show that the crystal belongs to Hobden’s class 3.
elements.clean_text: Large, stable, and optical quality nonlinear optical lithium d-isoascorbate monohydrate crystals crystallizing in the space group P212121 are grown from solution. They exhibit high birefringence, collinear and noncollinear phase matching, anisotropic dielectric relaxation, high laser damage thresholds, etc. The refractive indices and generated phase matching curves show that the crystal belongs to Hobden's class 3.

elements.content: Chiral molecules exist in two different forms (l and d) called enantiomers that are mirror images of each other. The physical and chemical properties of l and d enantiomers are identical in an achiral environment. However, their optical and nonlinear optical properties are generally very different. For example, enantiomers exhibit equal but opposite optical activity. Though the chiral molecules of an enantiomer pair have identical bond lengths and bond angles, their macroscopic arrangement in the crystalline state can be different (hence different lattice parameters), and this leads to the observed differences in their optical and nonlinear optical properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Chiral molecules exist in two different forms (l and d) called enantiomers that are mirror images of each other. The physical and chemical properties of l and d enantiomers are identical in an achiral environment. However, their optical and nonlinear optical properties are generally very different. For example, enantiomers exhibit equal but opposite optical activity. Though the chiral molecules of an enantiomer pair have identical bond lengths and bond angles, their macroscopic arrangement in the crystalline state can be different (hence different lattice parameters), and this leads to the observed differences in their optical and nonlinear optical properties.

elements.content: The enantiomers of ascorbic acid, l-ascorbic acid and d-isoascorbic acid, crystallize in the same space group P21, but with different lattice parameters. They exhibit almost identical physical and chemical properties. However, certain properties like the optical transmission range, band gap, second harmonic conversion efficiency, etc., are different. d-Isoascorbic acid has a second harmonic conversion efficiency which is five times that of l-ascorbic acid. However, these acids are not very stable in solution as well as in the crystalline state as they oxidize and degrade. Introduction of metal ions into such organic systems (so as to form metal salts) is likely to bring about greater chemical and physical stability. Apart from this, changes in structure brought about by the introduction of a metal ion, can positively affect the optical, nonlinear optical and other physical properties. In a recent work, we found that the lithium salt of l-ascorbic acid (lithium l-ascorbate dihydrate) is more stable in comparison to l-ascorbic acid, as the oxidation has already been affected by the metal ion. Lithium l-ascorbate dihydrate crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1. Our studies showed that this material not only has a higher chemical and physical stability, but also, larger second harmonic conversion efficiency in comparison to l-ascorbic acid.

elements.content: As a logical extension, we synthesized the lithium salt of d-isoascorbic acid, lithium d-isoascorbate monohydrate (LDAM), for a comparative study. Since the structure of LDAM was not known, we first proceeded with solving its structure. As expected (because of chirality) we found that the material crystallizes in a noncentrosymmetric space group. In this paper we discuss in detail the synthesis, the absolute configuration of the structure, growth and physical properties (with emphasis on nonlinear optical properties) of LDAM.

In this paper we discuss in detail the synthesis, the absolute configuration of the structure, growth and physical properties (with emphasis on nonlinear optical properties) of LDAM.

elements.content: LDAM was synthesized using stoichiometric proportion of d-isoascorbic acid (Sigma Aldrich 98%) and lithium carbonate (Sigma Aldrich 99%) in triple distilled water at room temperature. The solution was stirred till the evolution of carbon dioxide ceased. Care was taken to minimize exposure to air and light so as to avoid oxidation of d-isoascorbic acid. The crystals were clear and possessed totally different morphology compared to the lithium salt of l-ascorbic acid indicating a structural difference.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

LDAM was synthesized using stoichiometric proportion of d-isoascorbic acid (Sigma Aldrich 98%) and lithium carbonate (Sigma Aldrich 99%) in triple distilled water at room temperature. The solution was stirred till the evolution of carbon dioxide ceased. Care was taken to minimize exposure to air and light so as to avoid oxidation of d-isoascorbic acid. The crystals were clear and possessed totally different morphology compared to the lithium salt of l-ascorbic acid indicating a structural difference.

elements.content: The X-ray data of the title compound were collected on a Bruker AXS Kappa Apex CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated MoKα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. A crystal of suitable quality was selected and mounted on a Hampton cryo loop and cooled to 100 K in a stream of nitrogen using the “Oxford Cryosystems” cryostat. The crystal-to-detector distance was fixed at 40 mm. Data collection and subsequent data reduction were carried out with the Apex 2 software suite. The structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXS97, and the refinement was carried out using SHELXL97 included in the WinGx package suite. All the position and thermal parameters of non-hydrogen atoms were refined. The hydrogens attached to carbon atoms were fixed at stereochemically permitted locations and refined with a riding model, while the hydrogens attached to oxygen atoms were located from the difference Fourier map, and only their position and isotropic thermal parameters were allowed to refine. The ORTEP diagram for the compound was created using POV Ray, and the packing diagram was generated using the software Diamond.
elements.clean_text:
Structure

The X-ray data of the title compound were collected on a Bruker AXS Kappa Apex CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated MoKα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. A crystal of suitable quality was selected and mounted on a Hampton cryo loop and cooled to 100 K in a stream of nitrogen using the "Oxford Cryosystems" cryostat. The crystal-to-detector distance was fixed at 40 mm. Data collection and subsequent data reduction were carried out with the Apex 2 software suite. The structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXS97, and the refinement was carried out using SHELXL97 included in the WinGx package suite. All the position and thermal parameters of non-hydrogen atoms were refined. The hydrogens attached to carbon atoms were fixed at stereochemically permitted locations and refined with a riding model, while the hydrogens attached to oxygen atoms were located from the difference Fourier map, and only their position and isotropic thermal parameters were allowed to refine. The ORTEP diagram for the compound was created using POV Ray, and the packing diagram was generated using the software Diamond.

elements.content: The temperature dependence of solubility of LDAM in water was determined thermogravimetrically. As seen in Figure , the material has positive temperature coefficient of solubility which facilitates crystal growth by slow cooling. Accurate control of temperature is necessary as the solubility of the material is very high.
elements.clean_text:
Solubility and Crystal Growth

The temperature dependence of solubility of LDAM in water was determined thermogravimetrically. As seen in Figure , the material has positive temperature coefficient of solubility which facilitates crystal growth by slow cooling. Accurate control of temperature is necessary as the solubility of the material is very high.

elements.content: The synthesized compound in aqueous solution was transferred to the growth apparatus equipped with a Eurotherm temperature controller 2416. The solution was saturated at 40 °C. A seed crystal, obtained by solvent evaporation, was inserted into the solution, and the unit was cooled at the rate of 0.05 °C per hour. Under optimum conditions, high quality crystals of typical dimensions 20 mm × 14 mm × 12 mm were grown in about 10 days (see Figure ). The grown crystals were non-hygroscopic and highly stable.

Under optimum conditions, high quality crystals of typical dimensions 20 mm × 14 mm × 12 mm were grown in about 10 days (see Figure ). The grown crystals were non-hygroscopic and highly stable.

elements.content: To generate the morphology of the crystal, the interplanar angles were measured using a contact goniometer of least count of 0.1 deg. TGA was performed using Metler TGA/SDTA 851 and DSC using TA Instruments MDSC 2920. Dielectric spectroscopic studies were carried out employing an Agilent 4294A precision impedance analyzer with the frequency range 40–110 MHz. Cut and polished (with ethanol and Al2O3 powder) crystals were used for all optical measurements. The transmission spectrum of the crystal was recorded on a Bruker IFS 66v/s optical spectrometer. Refractive indices were determined using low power lasers of wavelengths of 405, 543, and 632.8 nm with the help of a spectrometer having a least count 1 arc sec employing Brewster’s angle method. An Nd:YAG laser (Brilliant B, Quantel) of 6 ns pulse width and 10 Hz repetition rate was used in TEM00 mode for phase matching and laser damage studies. The laser energy/power was measured employing a pyroelectric sensor (25BBDIF Ophir with/without diffuser) together with a power meter (Ophir).

elements.content: The crystallographic data are given in Table . The compound crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group P212121 and is isostructural with its sodium analogue. LDAM being a non-centrosymmetric compound, determination of its absolute configuration was necessary, but efforts to determine the absolute configuration uniquely were not conclusive since the value of the Flack parameter was 0.2(9). However, the current structure can be assumed to be the absolute structure since on inverting the coordinates of the compound the value of the Flack parameter obtained was 0.8(9). In addition, the Hooft parameter [−0.1(4)] is in support of this conclusion. In this structure the lithium ion is octahedrally coordinated, where five oxygen atoms are from four ascorbate moiety while one water molecule completes the coordination sphere. The compound forms extensive hydrogen bonds, which mediate its growth in three dimensions resulting in a bulky crystal. In addition there is an intramolecular hydrogen bonding involving the O5 and H2 atoms. The lithium atom is bonded to O4 and O5 from the same ascorbate moiety, thus forming a chelate. The packing diagram (Figure b) clearly depicts the octahedral coordination of lithium.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure

The crystallographic data are given in Table . The compound crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group P212121 and is isostructural with its sodium analogue. LDAM being a non-centrosymmetric compound, determination of its absolute configuration was necessary, but efforts to determine the absolute configuration uniquely were not conclusive since the value of the Flack parameter was 0.2(9). However, the current structure can be assumed to be the absolute structure since on inverting the coordinates of the compound the value of the Flack parameter obtained was 0.8(9). In addition, the Hooft parameter [-0.1(4)] is in support of this conclusion. In this structure the lithium ion is octahedrally coordinated, where five oxygen atoms are from four ascorbate moiety while one water molecule completes the coordination sphere. The compound forms extensive hydrogen bonds, which mediate its growth in three dimensions resulting in a bulky crystal. In addition there is an intramolecular hydrogen bonding involving the O5 and H2 atoms. The lithium atom is bonded to O4 and O5 from the same ascorbate moiety, thus forming a chelate. The packing diagram (Figure b) clearly depicts the octahedral coordination of lithium.

elements.content:
The presence of screw axis along b is discernable in 100 projection. For the list of various hydrogen bonds present in the crystal structure refer to the .

Morphology

The morphology of the crystal was generated with the help of the software WinXmorph which depicts an ideal morphology based on inputs from space group and lattice parameters data. We chose an upper limit for (hkl) values and selected only those faces that appeared in the grown crystals. By varying the central distances of the faces from the origin of the model, a morphology that is identical to the actual crystal was generated. The crystals possess a bulky morphology with a prismatic habit and are slightly elongated along the b-axis (Figure ). The crystal has a cleavage normal to the b-axis. This is presumably due to the large number of hydrogen bonds along the b axis which connect the adjacent layers containing Li atoms. Among the prominent faces the c face appears as the only principal morphological face. All measured interfacial angles were matched with theoretical values. Table illustrates typical theoretical and measured interfacial angles.

The recorded TGA and DSC (Figure ) curves indicate that the crystals are stable up to 120 °C. A step in the DSC curve near 120 °C is due to an endothermic process such as vaporization of crystallized water. The change in the slope of TGA curve around 120 °C indicates the beginning of vaporization of crystallized water, and this continues to occur up to 146.9 °C. For a mass of 0.804 mg (initial mass of the compound in our case), a weight loss of 0.07 mg would correspond to complete removal of water of crystallization from the lattice. However the weight loss, up to 146.9 °C (the point of second slope change), is only 0.029 mg. This indicates that decomposition sets in before all the crystallized water could escape, due to instability of the lattice because of partial loss of crystallized water. The fluctuations in the DSC curve beyond 146.9 °C confirm the decomposition. Vaporization of crystallized water and decomposition upon melting is observed in other hydrated saccharides also.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis

The recorded TGA and DSC (Figure ) curves indicate that the crystals are stable up to 120 °C. A step in the DSC curve near 120 °C is due to an endothermic process such as vaporization of crystallized water. The change in the slope of TGA curve around 120 °C indicates the beginning of vaporization of crystallized water, and this continues to occur up to 146.9 °C. For a mass of 0.804 mg (initial mass of the compound in our case), a weight loss of 0.07 mg would correspond to complete removal of water of crystallization from the lattice. However the weight loss, up to 146.9 °C (the point of second slope change), is only 0.029 mg. This indicates that decomposition sets in before all the crystallized water could escape, due to instability of the lattice because of partial loss of crystallized water. The fluctuations in the DSC curve beyond 146.9 °C confirm the decomposition. Vaporization of crystallized water and decomposition upon melting is observed in other hydrated saccharides also.

elements.content: Several investigations are devoted to dielectric spectroscopy of saccharides as a tool to understand the molecular dynamics and relaxation mechanisms. However most of them deal with saccharides in solutions. We have investigated the dielectric properties of LDAM in the crystalline state. The dielectric measurements were performed on (100), (010), and (001) plates of thicknesses 0.84 mm, 0.90 mm and 0.85 mm respectively. Silver paste was applied to the surfaces and the sample was kept at 80 °C for about 3 h for drying. The frequency dependence of the real and complex parts of dielectric constant along with loss D for three orientations is shown in Figure .

Dielectric Spectroscopy and Optical Transmission

Several investigations are devoted to dielectric spectroscopy of saccharides as a tool to understand the molecular dynamics and relaxation mechanisms. However most of them deal with saccharides in solutions. We have investigated the dielectric properties of LDAM in the crystalline state. The dielectric measurements were performed on (100), (010), and (001) plates of thicknesses 0.84 mm, 0.90 mm and 0.85 mm respectively. Silver paste was applied to the surfaces and the sample was kept at 80 °C for about 3 h for drying. The frequency dependence of the real and complex parts of dielectric constant along with loss D for three orientations is shown in Figure .

elements.content: As can be seen from Figure , the Cole–Cole plots are semicircles with their origins below the ε′ axis. It is noted that the peak relaxation time changes with orientation. The dielectric strength (εs – ε∞) is also observed to be different along the three principal orientations. The near Debye type Cole–Cole behavior is similar to that shown by lithium l-ascorbate dihydrate, with only the peak relaxation frequencies being different. Convergence for least-squares fitting (for b plate) was obtained for α ∼ 0.1 (see Figure ). This shows that there is more than one relaxation time and their distribution is spread over a narrow range.

elements.content: Many saccharide materials possess large optical activity, and the standard minimum deviation method for the determination of refractive indices may not be very appropriate unless proper corrections are incorporated. Hence, the refractive indices were determined by employing Brewster’s angle method following the procedure given by Smet. Grossman and Garito have demonstrated that Brewster’s angle method can be employed to measure the refractive indices of biaxial crystals with an accuracy of 0.001. A plane polarized laser beam is incident on the polished face of the crystal mounted on a spectrometer as illustrated in Figure . The intensity of the reflected light is monitored as the crystal is rotated, and the angle, at which the intensity becomes zero, is taken as the Brewster’s angle θB.
elements.clean_text:
Refractive Index Measurements

Many saccharide materials possess large optical activity, and the standard minimum deviation method for the determination of refractive indices may not be very appropriate unless proper corrections are incorporated. Hence, the refractive indices were determined by employing Brewster's angle method following the procedure given by Smet. Grossman and Garito have demonstrated that Brewster's angle method can be employed to measure the refractive indices of biaxial crystals with an accuracy of 0.001. A plane polarized laser beam is incident on the polished face of the crystal mounted on a spectrometer as illustrated in Figure . The intensity of the reflected light is monitored as the crystal is rotated, and the angle, at which the intensity becomes zero, is taken as the Brewster's angle θB.

For measurements along the three crystallographic directions, plates of (100), (010) and (001) orientations were cut and polished. For three different orientations we obtain three simultaneous equations which were solved to get the values of the principal refractive indices n a, n b, and n c. The selection of a polarizer with an excellent extinction coefficient was crucial in the experiment. Reference measurements made on a KDP crystal using the same set up and the procedure were accurate up to the third decimal place.

elements.content: LDAM belongs to the orthorhombic point group 222. The refractive index measurements reveal that it is a negative biaxial crystal with its optic axes lying in the XZ plane. The crystallographic direction a lies along the Z axis, b along the X axis, and c along the Y axis as shown in Figure . The angle between the Z axis and the optic axes is calculated as V z = 53.9° at 405 nm. The refractive indices at 532 and 1064 nm were calculated using the Sellmeier equation. Table lists the refractive indices along with the birefringence at three wavelengths and the Sellmeier equations. Figure shows the fitted curves for the refractive indices vs wavelength plot.

The generated curves of θ vs ϕ are shown in Figure with the experimentally determined phase matching angles shown as dots. The curves are consistent with orthorhombic point group symmetry 222. For the determination of experimental phase matching angles, a (010) plate was mounted on a goniometer fixed on a rotation stage (Thorlabs). Rotation of the (010) plate about the c axis and a axis enabled the scanning of type 1 and type 2 phase matching curves. No other phase matching direction, apart from the ones given by the curves, was observed experimentally since the (100) as well as the (001) plates rotated about different axes did not result in second harmonic generation.

elements.content: LDAM is an “optically well behaved crystal” based on the criteria put forth by Hobden. In optically well behaved crystals principal axes do not change direction with frequency, and the dispersions are normal, small, and approximately equal between the fundamental and second harmonic frequencies.
elements.clean_text: LDAM is an "optically well behaved crystal" based on the criteria put forth by Hobden. In optically well behaved crystals principal axes do not change direction with frequency, and the dispersions are normal, small, and approximately equal between the fundamental and second harmonic frequencies.

elements.content: Upon assuming the Kleinman symmetry condition for crystals belonging to an orthorhombic point group 222, we have d 14 = d 25 = d 36. Hence there is only one nonvanishing independent tensor component for LDAM. The effective nonlinear coefficients for type 1 and type 2 phase matching were calculated using the following relations. d eff ( type 1 ) = d 14 [ sin ⁡ 2 θ cos ⁡ 2 ϕ cos ⁡ δ ( 3 sin 2 ⁡ δ − 1 ) + sin ⁡ θ sin ⁡ 2 ϕ sin ⁡ δ ( 3 cos 2 ⁡ θ cos 2 ⁡ δ + 3 cos 2 ⁡ δ − 1 ) ] and d eff ( type 2 ) = d 14 [ sin ⁡ 2 θ cos ⁡ 2 ϕ sin ⁡ δ ( 3 cos 2 ⁡ δ − 1 ) − sin ⁡ θ sin ⁡ 2 ϕ cos ⁡ δ ( 3 cos 2 ⁡ θ sin 2 ⁡ δ + 3 sin 2 ⁡ δ − 1 ) ] where the data of θ and ϕ are taken from the phase matching curves and δ is defined by cot ⁡ 2 δ = ( cot 2 ⁡ Ω sin 2 ⁡ θ − cos 2 ⁡ θ cos 2 ⁡ ϕ + sin 2 ⁡ ϕ ) / ( cos ⁡ θ sin ⁡ 2 ϕ ) In the above equation, Ω is the angle between the optic axis and the z axis calculated at 1064 nm. Figure shows the dependence of the relative values of effective nonlinear coefficient |d eff/d 14| on the phase matching angle θ at 1064 nm radiation. The maximum values of |d eff/d 14| for type 1 and type 2 phase matching occur at (θ = 45.8°, ϕ = 17.7°) and (74.5°, 30.2°) respectively. The |d eff/d 14| values vanish at (37.4°, 0°), (48.9°, 18.7°) and (69.4°, 0°) for type 1 and at (18.8°, 0°) and (43.9°, 39.9°) for type 2. The highest |d eff/d 14| is for type 2 at (74.5°, 30.2°), and calculation from eq yields the maximum value of the effective nonlinear coefficient d eff, max (type 2) ≈ 0.84d 14.

elements.content: Conversion efficiency measurements were made on a 5 mm thick LDAM crystal under the optimum phase matching (type 2) direction θ = 74.5° and ϕ = 30.2°. A KDP crystal of same thickness under type 1 phase matching was used as a reference for the experiment. Comparing the conversion efficiencies under exactly identical conditions, we determined the nonlinear coefficient of LDAM d 14 ≈ 1.6 times that of d 36 of KDP = 1.6 (0.44 pm/V) ≈ 7 × 10–13 m/V. We also observed SHG rings due to noncollinear (vectorial) phase matching. Up to the third ring could be clearly seen. Only those crystals that possess moderate to large birefringence and high nonlinear coefficients, along certain directions, can produce noncollinear phase matching. As the crystal was rotated, transfer of energy from rings to collinear phase matching and vice versa was observed.
elements.clean_text: Conversion efficiency measurements were made on a 5 mm thick LDAM crystal under the optimum phase matching (type 2) direction θ = 74.5° and ϕ = 30.2°. A KDP crystal of same thickness under type 1 phase matching was used as a reference for the experiment. Comparing the conversion efficiencies under exactly identical conditions, we determined the nonlinear coefficient of LDAM d 14 ~ 1.6 times that of d 36 of KDP = 1.6 (0.44 pm/V) ~ 7 × 10-13 m/V. We also observed SHG rings due to noncollinear (vectorial) phase matching. Up to the third ring could be clearly seen. Only those crystals that possess moderate to large birefringence and high nonlinear coefficients, along certain directions, can produce noncollinear phase matching. As the crystal was rotated, transfer of energy from rings to collinear phase matching and vice versa was observed.

elements.content: Along the phase-matching direction the energy flow vectors of the fundamental and the second harmonic beams are oriented at a small angle referred to as the walk off angle. This walk off angle limits the second harmonic conversion efficiency.
elements.clean_text:
Walk off Angle

Along the phase-matching direction the energy flow vectors of the fundamental and the second harmonic beams are oriented at a small angle referred to as the walk off angle. This walk off angle limits the second harmonic conversion efficiency.

For a nonlinear optical crystal surface, the laser damage threshold value becomes a critical factor as most applications involve focusing of pulsed lasers which often leads to high power densities. This necessitates evaluation of damage threshold values. Both single shot and multiple shot damage thresholds were determined for LDAM using an Nd:YAG laser of 6 ns pulse width and 10 Hz frequency in TEM00 mode. For multiple shot damage studies, we have employed the procedure defined by Nakatani. The laser beam was focused on the surface of the crystal using a plano convex lens of focal length 30 cm. The diffraction limited spot size was calculated using the formula, d ′ = ( 4 M 2 λ f ) / ( π d ) where M 2 is the beam quality factor (has a value 2 for the laser used), λ is the wavelength of the laser, f is the focal length of the lens, and d is the diameter of the laser at the beam waist. For an aperture of 4.5 mm diameter at the beam waist, the calculated spot sizes for 1064 and 532 nm radiation were 180 and 90 μm respectively. The onset of damage was monitored by observing the reduction in intensity of a He–Ne laser passing collinearly with the pulsed laser through the same spot where damage was being produced. Examination of the spot under an optical microscope, subsequently, confirmed the damage. The beginning of damage typically causes a reduction of around 5% in the intensity of the He–Ne laser along with a damage site clearly visible under a microscope. Figure a,b shows the damage thresholds as a function of number of pulses for 1064 and 532 nm radiation, respectively. The data were obtained for three different (010) plates of the LDAM crystal and the same are shown in these figures. It is seen that the damage threshold saturates beyond 1000 pulses. The average multiple surface damage thresholds are found to be 18 GW/cm2 and 8 GW/cm2 for 1064 and 532 nm respectively. Since the crystal is anisotropic, we presume that the damage threshold will be different on different planes. The asymmetric nature of the damaged spots shown in Figure also supports this view. However, we have determined the damage thresholds only for the (010) plates. We observed that the bulk internal damage threshold of the crystal is an order of magnitude higher when compared to the surface damage threshold. At spots nearer to imperfections in the crystal, we observed that the damage occurred at lower power densities.

elements.content: Figure shows the damage patterns for a (010) plate. Since (010) is the cleavage plane, we can see colors due to interference effects caused by reflections of light at microscopic layers cleaved as a result of damage. This interference effect is observable only for the (010) plate. Figure shows a damage site on the surface of a (001) plate. The cleavage plane which is normal to the observation plane is revealed as a straight line in the damage patterns.

elements.content: The structure of lithium d-isoascorbate monohydrate was solved using single crystal XRD. The crystal belongs to the non-centrosymmetric space group P212121. The chiral nature of the saccharide molecule ensures the non-centrosymmetry as all chiral space groups are also non-centrosymmetric. Large size optical quality crystals were grown from aqueous solution. The 3D nature of hydrogen bonding enabled the growth of the crystals of large dimensions. The crystals are very stable when compared to d-isoascorbic acid crystals. The addition of lithium not only has changed the structure from monoclinic to orthorhombic, but also has brought in greater stability. Dielectric spectroscopy revealed Cole–Cole type behavior and anisotropic relaxation with different peak relaxation frequencies. Since the crystal has high birefringence, SHG rings due to noncollinear phase matching were observed. The crystal belongs to Hobden’s class 3. The generated type 1 and type 2 phase matching curves display a behavior consistent with the point group symmetry 222 of the crystal. The crystal also possesses very high surface laser damage thresholds.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The structure of lithium d-isoascorbate monohydrate was solved using single crystal XRD. The crystal belongs to the non-centrosymmetric space group P212121. The chiral nature of the saccharide molecule ensures the non-centrosymmetry as all chiral space groups are also non-centrosymmetric. Large size optical quality crystals were grown from aqueous solution. The 3D nature of hydrogen bonding enabled the growth of the crystals of large dimensions. The crystals are very stable when compared to d-isoascorbic acid crystals. The addition of lithium not only has changed the structure from monoclinic to orthorhombic, but also has brought in greater stability. Dielectric spectroscopy revealed Cole-Cole type behavior and anisotropic relaxation with different peak relaxation frequencies. Since the crystal has high birefringence, SHG rings due to noncollinear phase matching were observed. The crystal belongs to Hobden's class 3. The generated type 1 and type 2 phase matching curves display a behavior consistent with the point group symmetry 222 of the crystal. The crystal also possesses very high surface laser damage thresholds.

cln_elements.content:
The recorded TGA and DSC (Figure ) curves indicate that the crystals are stable up to 120 °C. A step in the DSC curve near 120 °C is due to an endothermic process such as vaporization of crystallized water. The change in the slope of TGA curve around 120 °C indicates the beginning of vaporization of crystallized water, and this continues to occur up to 146.9 °C. For a mass of 0.804 mg (initial mass of the compound in our case), a weight loss of 0.07 mg would correspond to complete removal of water of crystallization from the lattice. However the weight loss, up to 146.9 °C (the point of second slope change), is only 0.029 mg. This indicates that decomposition sets in before all the crystallized water could escape, due to instability of the lattice because of partial loss of crystallized water. The fluctuations in the DSC curve beyond 146.9 °C confirm the decomposition. Vaporization of crystallized water and decomposition upon melting is observed in other hydrated saccharides also.

The optical transmission spectrum recorded for a 2 mm thick finely polished b plate of the crystal is shown in Figure . The crystal has a lower cut off wavelength of 310 nm, and the transmission range extends up to 1400 nm. The optical band gap calculated from the lower cut off is 4.2 eV.
